qas.question: Who invented the idea of a "table-of-commonsense"?
Who came up with the idea of "things-as-interacted-by-us"?
Who spoke of the "warning signs" of idealism?
What sort of philosopher was Richard Rorty?
What hyphenated term did Musgrave coin?
What did Immanuel Kant call warning signs?
Who argued against issues of hermeneutics?
What kind of philosopher was Musgrave?

context: and proliferation of <b7_0>hyphenated entities<b7_0/> such as "<b6_0>thing-in-itself<b6_0/>" (<a0_0>Immanuel Kant<a0_0/>), "things-as-interacted-by-us" (<a2_0>Arthur Fine<a2_0/>), "table-of-commonsense" and "table-of-physics" (<a1_0>Sir Arthur Eddington<a1_0/>) which are "warning signs" for conceptual idealism according to <a3_0>Musgrave<a3_0/> because they allegedly do not exist but only highlight the numerous ways in which people come to know the world. This argument does not take into account the issues pertaining to hermeneutics, especially at the backdrop of analytic philosophy. <b5_0>Musgrave<b5_0/> criticized <b8_0>Richard Rorty<b8_0/> and <a4_0><b9_0>Postmodernist<b9_0/><a4_0/> philosophy in general for confusion of use and mention.
